awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Internet of things for Construction Safety
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a system that fully integrates internet-of-things technology in the construction industry. The U.S. construction industry is one of the largest markets in the nation and makes up a substantial portion of the U.S. economy. In 2016, this sector attributed 6.1 percent of all industry employment and 4.2 percent of the gross domestic product. However, the construction industry is one of the least productive and most dangerous industries. In the past two decades, more than 28,000 U.S. construction workers have died at work. Internet-of-things-based technologies have been implemented as a solution to meet the many needs of the construction industry, but there have been many barriers that prohibit the full implementation of these technologies. The team has identified multiple deployment challenges, including 1) interoperability of internet-of-things components, 2) consistent operation within harsh environments typical of the construction industry, and 3) lack of service and other data quality issues inherent to remote environments.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an interoperable system that enables the data connectivity of an intelligent construction jobsite. Construction sites have been quickly implementing internet of things-based technologies to aid in the safety and productivity of their workers. This system networks these devices and data streams for optimal use. The most numerous sensors used in the field are vision-based systems for safety monitoring and hazard detection, and real-time worker physiological monitoring systems to prevent fatigue and heatstroke. This technology will bridge the output from the sensors and apply artificial intelligence and multi-access edge computing to optimize the input of data traffic that accumulates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project evaluated the commercial potential of intellectual property derived from academic research, with a focus on advancing technology in the construction industry. The primary goals were to justify research into computerized personal protective equipment (PPE) for construction workers by assessing its market potential and return on investment, and to gather industry feedback to guide future research.

During the course of the project, we made a significant pivot from focusing on PPE to concentrating on communication technology. This shift addresses a more immediate and impactful need: enhancing connectivity in increasingly complex and dynamic environments. The development of communication technologies will have lasting implications not only for construction but also for a range of industries facing similar connectivity challenges.

1. Intellectual Merit
The project revealed significant findings regarding the intersection of technology and construction, particularly focusing on wireless communication frameworks for dynamic and challenging environments like construction sites. Over the course of the project, the team conducted over 150 interviews with industry professionals, including superintendents, field engineers, and technology vendors. These interviews provided invaluable insights into the specific technological needs and challenges faced by the construction industry.

Initially, the research was focused on embedding computing into PPE for safety improvements. However, industry feedback led to a shift in focus toward communication technologies that enhance connectivity between workers and construction technologies on-site. This shift represents a more immediate and impactful area of technological advancement, particularly in improving communication protocols that operate on varying frequencies and meet the demands of complex construction environments.

The project also developed key market insights, including estimates of total available market, serviceable market, and customer acquisition costs, which further validated the commercial potential of the technology.

2. Broader Impacts
The broader impact of this project extends beyond construction, addressing the need for robust wireless communication in dynamic and remote environments. The solutions developed have potential applications in other industries, such as agriculture and rural development, where connectivity is a challenge.

Additionally, this project has had a meaningful impact on education and training. The research findings are now incorporated into the curriculum for construction management students, helping to bridge the knowledge gap between technological development and real-world construction challenges. By integrating communication development kits into classroom materials, we’ve made it easier for non-technical majors to engage with technology in a meaningful way, helping to foster a new generation of tech-savvy construction professionals.

The establishment of Kyaron Technologies, Inc. also highlights the success of this project in transferring academic research into a commercial venture. We plan on submitting to  NSF Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) to continue paving the way for future business ventures in construction technology.

3. Technological and Societal Impact
One of the major technological contributions of this project is the advancement of multi-protocol, multi-frequency communication systems. These systems are crucial not only for construction sites but also for any location with limited infrastructure or significant wireless interference. The integration of diverse microelectronics supporting various communication protocols opens up new possibilities for robust and scalable wireless networks.

On a broader societal level, the findings of this project contribute to the growing need for connectivity in underserved or complex environments. As society becomes more reliant on wireless communication, this research has the potential to impact numerous sectors, improving wireless technology's resilience and adaptability. Future applications of this research could help extend connectivity to rural areas, agricultural zones, and highly dense urban environments.


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Aaron Costin
